i saw a few people struggling with the second question, so here's the explanation:  1. sort out the brackets, 4-7 is -3 2. sort out the fraction, 4/2 is 2 3. you see that little minus before the brackets? - (-3)? that's going to change it to PLUS 3.  i'll explain this in more detail. see, the "-"? it has no number in front of it (no coefficient) so we consider the number to be 1. then, it will look like -1(-3), which is -1 x -3, which will give us +3. two negatives cancel each other out to make a positive. so far our equation is 5 + (3) + 2 (<-- there is no need for the brackets) 4. then, just add 5 + 3, which is 8, +2 it's going to be 10. hope this helped! sorry for my english lol

im not sure if you still need help, but i got 10 as my answer, and i'll explain what i did.  1. sort out the brackets, 4-7 is -3 2. sort out the fraction, 4/2 is 2 3. you see that little minus before the brackets? - (-3)? that's going to change it to PLUS 3.  i'll explain this in more detail. see, the "-"? it has no number in front of it (no coefficient) so we consider the number to be 1. then, it will look like -1(-3), which is -1 x -3, which will give us +3. two negatives cancel each other out to make a positive. so far our equation is 5 + (3) + 2 (<-- there is no need for the brackets) 4. then, just add 5 + 3, which is 8, +2 it's going to be 10. hope this helped! sorry for my english lol

it's been 5 months but hopefully you still see this: PEMDAS despite having 6 letters for each operation really only has 4 steps, and should be better written as P-E-MD-AS; that's because what really happens is: 1. Solve parentheses left to right 2. Solve exponentiations left to right 3. Solve multiplication AND division left to right 4. Solve addition AND subtraction left to right The common error lies in solving multiplications then divisions, or solving additions then subtractions, when in reality they are both done in the same step, in order left to right.

The substance of both rules is the same.  Just different names for what each kind of symbol is called.

I was actually sort of upset to not have it mentioned in the video, but your hunch is right, there's a good reason for this specific order. It comes down to properties and definitions of operations that are covered in more detail in different videos.   To make a concrete example, consider 6 + 4 * 2. Blindly following PEMDAS, 6 + 8 = 14, which is correct. But more importantly, multiplication is repeated addition. You could just write 4 * 2 as 2 + 2 + 2 +2, the order for 6 + 2 + 2 + 2 + 2 is obvious, or rather irrelevant. you can do the those five additions in any order, because of it's cumulative property. Parenthesis are not even operations, simply ways to show stuff like 4 * 2 as something like (1 + 3) * 2 for situations where it makes sense.  If you didn't know pemdas or had the more useful general understanding, you might do 6 + 4, THEN * 2. But notice, that would change the fundamentals of the question. (6 + 4) * (2) is not the same as (6) + (4 * 2), because addition and multiplication can not be rewritten this way while keeping the same end result. The notation we are using in modernity is just that, notation. If we only teach a way to read it "aloud", instead of what it actually says, a lot of the use is lost in my opinion.   Another qualm I have with PEMDAS, is that Division is actually just multiplication by the inverse of the number you used for the division. 5/2 is really just 5 * 2^(-1). Subtraction is actually just addition by the negative of the number you used for the addition. 5 - 2 is really just 5 + (-2). There's historical and higher concept reasons for not generalizing like this in every case, but it's not like those are taught in school before you learn of PEMDAS anyway. If you consider only Exponentiation, Multiplication and Addition, the reason for the order is a lot clearer. E is Many M, M is many A, so we go from the top until everything is just addition. When doing algebra it's useful to go the other direction sometimes, and group additions into multiplications to solve more difficult problems, but the point is to preserve the value of the line while computing things, not to stick to an order handed down from on high.   If you were to come up with a different order that is as rigorous as PEMDAS's origins, you would have to redefine/restructure these operations in a way that changes their properties, basically start a completely new math.

12/4+2(1+3)^2-9  First complete the bracket 1+3=4 Then square it 4^2=16 Then times by 2 2x16=32 Then complete the first division 12/4=3 Then go left to right with the resulting equation 3+32-9=26  Took me a while but I figured it out.

Overall: The "PEMDAS rule" is supposed to help you remember to finish all multiplication and division before you do any addition and subtraction. You can in fact do division and multiplication in any order you like. Then you can do addition and subtraction in any order you like. PEMDAS is a nice help, but is not the whole story. (try it out! for example (2*3)/6 and (2/6)*3 or any combination you like!)  For you first question: If you take what I said above into account we get 15 + 25 = 40 40 - 54 = -14 -14 + 8 = -6 Another way to look at it is that everything is addition: 15 + 25 + (-54) + 8 = -6 (Dave explains this consept in his video on negative numbers)  For you second question: Why don't I show you how I would do it, and you can compare it to what you tried: 12/4 + 2(1 + 3)^2 - 9 12/4 + 2(4)^2 - 9        -> Parenthesis 12/4 + 2(16) - 9          -> Exponent (also I notice the implied multiplication between 2 and 16 for my next step) 3 + 32 - 9                     -> Multiply and Divide 26                                 -> Add and Subtract  I hope this was more helpfull than confusing!

If it helpful to think of PEMDAS as: P -> E -> MD -> A?  First doing parentheses left to right.  Then doing all exponents from left to right.  Then doing all multiplication and division from left to right.  Then doing all additional from left to right.  There would be no subtraction because would force ourselves to see would be subtractions as additions of negative numbers?

When nothing is written we assume that the operation is multiplication. So we get 3(11-9) = 3*(11-9) and 2(1+3) = 2*(1+3). But remember to resolve the parenthesis first, 2*(4)!  Why do we do this? It is simply because we are lazy, and want to write is as simply as possible. Just like we would rather write 5*5 instead of  5+5+5+5+5. It may seem confusing at first, but you get used to it, and it is very helpfull when the equations get more complicated :)
